intro: Quercus calliprinos var. arcuata, commonly known as the coast live oak, is a variant of the coast live oak native to coastal regions of California. It is a deciduous evergreen tree with thick, leathery leaves that are typically 3–6 inches long. The tree produces small, cup-shaped acorns that are an important food source for local wildlife. It has a slow growth rate and is adapted to coastal climates with mild winters and dry summers. The bark is usually smooth and gray, with a rugged texture that provides habitat for various insects and birds.
